keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican mayoral candidate, is under pressure from his boss John Catsimatidis to drop out of the race.
John Catsimatidis, a longtime New Yorker and owner of WABC radio, publicly urged Sliwa to exit, citing a need for Sliwa to love New York more than any political ambition.
Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, is rallying Republicans to oppose Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, and is pushing Sliwa to withdraw to consolidate opposition against Mamdani.

Sliwa has rejected the pressure, asserting that voters—especially blue-collar working-class people—should have the final say, and criticizing Cuomo and billionaire donors for trying to dictate outcomes.
Trump dismissed Sliwa as 'not exactly primetime,' mocking his interest in cats and animal rescues, indicating broader Republican skepticism.
Mamdani has dismissed claims of coordination between him and Sliwa, emphasizing that New Yorkers should make their own decisions, not be influenced by billionaire donors.
Sliwa, known for founding the Guardian Angels, has never held elected office and is polling third in the mayoral race.
The political dynamics reflect a growing tension between grassroots, working-class candidates and wealthy donors, with Sliwa positioning himself as a defender of blue-collar interests.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate running for mayor of New York City, is under increasing pressure to withdraw from the race after his boss, John Catsimatidis, publicly urged him to step down, citing a need for greater love of New York. Catsimatidis, who owns WABC radio where Sliwa hosts a show, is part of a broader Republican effort—led by Andrew Cuomo, who is running as an independent—to oppose Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani by consolidating opposition. Sliwa has rejected this pressure, arguing that voters, particularly blue-collar working-class New Yorkers, should have the final say, and criticizing both Cuomo and billionaire donors like Bill Ackman for attempting to dictate political outcomes. Trump dismissed Sliwa as unimpressive and mocked his cat-related interests, further undermining his appeal. The article highlights a growing tension between grassroots, community-based candidates and wealthy political donors, with Sliwa positioning himself as a defender of the working class against elite influence.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
